biogHist.abstract: Benmore Presbyterian Children's Home (often known as Benmore Farm Training School) was established by the Council Presbyterian Children's Homes in 1947 in Caversham. Originally, it was an agricultural school for older boys but by 1956 girls and boys as young as 5 years old were placed at Benmore. Children who were wards of the state and private children were admitted. Benmore had closed by 1963.
biogHist.p: Benmore Presbyterian Children's Home was established by the Council Presbyterian Children's Homes as a farm school for older boys. The official opening and dedication ceremony was held on 17 May 1947.

In 1954, Benmore was described as being able to accommodate 35 boys aged from 10 years. Renovations were proposed in 1954, with the addition of a dining and recreation hall to be known as the 'Withnell Memorial Hall', and new kitchen, laundry and ablution block.

By 1956, Benmore admitted children from under 6 years, both boys and girls. Children who were wards of the state were placed at Benmore, and most children were 'private admissions'. Younger children went to Middle Swan Primary School and others attended Midland Junction High School.
Benmore closed in the 1962-1963 financial year, possibly at the end of the 1962 school year.

chronItem.event: Location - Benmore Presbyterian Children's Home was situated on 20 hectares of land along the Swan River on Middle Swan Road, Caversham

cpfRelation.relationEntry: State Archives Collection of Western Australia (1829 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Benmore and Burnbrae were the two Homes run by the Council Presbyterian Children's Homes. By mid-1957, all the children from Burnbrae had been transferred to Benmore.

archref.repository: Uniting Church (Synod of Western Australia) Uniting Church Children's Homes File, Western Australia Archives
archref.unittitle: Dedication and Official Opening of Benmore
archref.abstract: 'Dedication and Official Opening of Benmore' is a digital copy of the program printed for the opening of the Benmore Presbyterian Children's Home in 1947. It has images and history about the Benmore and Burnbrae Presbyterian Children's Homes, a plan of Benmore and a list of the Home's 'needs'. A photocopy of this program is held in the Uniting Church (Synod of Western Australia) Archives.
archref.note: Uniting Church (Synod of Western Australia), Archives

resourceRelation.relationEntry: The Children's Homes, 1953 [Presbyterian Children's Home Council, excerpt]

archref.repository: Uniting Church (Synod of Western Australia) Uniting Church Children's Homes File, Western Australia Archives
archref.unittitle: The Children's Homes, 1953 [Presbyterian Children's Home Council, excerpt]
archref.abstract: 'The Children's Homes, 1953 [Presbyterian Children's Home Council, excerpt]' is a digital copy of an excerpt from a report given to the Presbyterian Church by the committee that ran the Burnbrae and Benmore Presbyterian Children's Homes. A photocopy of this report is held in the Uniting Church (Synod of Western Australia) Archives.
archref.note: Uniting Church (Synod of Western Australia), Archives

resourceRelation.relationEntry: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II

archref.unittitle: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II
archref.abstract: This is a file held online by the National Archives of Australia. It has draft reports on the Australian institutions which took unaccompanied British child migrants after World War Two.
This picture of Benmore at Caversham was used in the progamme for the official opening of the Home in 1947.
